title: Poland’s Commission candidate returns EU funds after probe
text:
Janusz Wojciechowski, Poland's nominee for European commissioner | Julien Warnand/EPA Poland’s Commission candidate returns EU funds after probe OLAF said Janusz Wojciechowski had ‘unduly’ received €11,243 in travel and living expenses when he was an MEP.

Poland's nominee for the next European Commission has paid back more than €11,000 after a probe by the EU's anti-fraud agency.

OLAF concluded that Janusz Wojciechowski, nominated to be the bloc's next agriculture commissioner, had "unduly" received €11,243 in travel and living expenses from the European Parliament between 2004 and 2016, when he was an MEP.

Announcing the end of a probe that was launched in July 2016, OLAF said in a statement: "No disciplinary or judicial recommendations have been made concerning Mr Wojciechowski in person."

OLAF said Wojciechowski, a member of the European Court of Auditors, had already paid the money back to the Parliament, confirming what he told German media earlier this month.

The news comes after the European Parliament's legal affairs committee rejected two of Ursula von der Leyen's picks for the Commission, Romania's Rovana Plumb and Hungary's László Trócsányi, citing concerns about conflicts of interest.

The same committee approved Wojciechowski's declaration of financial interests. He faces his make-or-break hearing before the agriculture committee on October 1.
description: OLAF said Janusz Wojciechowski had ‘unduly’ received €11,243 in travel and living expenses when he was an MEP.
